title-group.article-title: Open-holed trapdoor spiders of the genus Teyl (Mygalomorphae: Nemesiidae Anamini) from Western Australia’s Pilbara bioregion: a new species and expanded phylogenetic assessment

sec.p: Open-holed trapdoor spiders of the genus Teyl (Mygalomorphae: Nemesiidae : Anamini) from Western Australia’s Pilbara bioregion: a new species and expanded phylogenetic assessment
JOEL A. HUEY1,2,3,5 , MICHAEL G. RIX4,1 , JEREMY D. WILSON4 , MIA J. HILLYER1 & MARK S. HARVEY1,21 Department of Terrestrial Zoology, Western Australian Museum, Welshpool, WA 6106, Australia .
2 School of Animal Biology, The University of Western Australia , Crawley, WA 6009, Australia .
3 School of Natural Sciences, Edith Cowan University, Joondalup, WA 6027, Australia .
4 Biodiversity and Geosciences Program, Queensland Museum, South Brisbane, QLD 4101, Australia .
5Corresponding author. E-mail: joel.huey@museum.wa.gov.au

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p: The open-holed trapdoor spiders of the genus TeylMain, 1975 from the Pilbara bioregion of Western Australia are investigated. A single endemic species from the southern Pilbara, T. heuretes sp. nov. , is newly described, representing the northern-most occurrence of the genus in Australia . Legacy molecular data for Australian Nemesiidae , along with newly generated sequences for all described species of Teyl known from Western Australia , are analysed using Maximum Likelihood methods, providing molecular data for T. heuretes and an expanded phylogenetic assessment of the genus.
Key words: biogeography, Crassitarsae, new species, taxonomy

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The open-holed trapdoor spiders of the genus TeylMain, 1975 are a poorly documented yet widely distributed group of Anamini Simon, 1889 endemic to Australia , with a range that extends from the Indian Ocean coastline of Western Australia east to at least western Victoria (
Harvey et al. 2018
). Like the co-occurring taxa Idiosoma Ausserer, 1871
(family
Idiopidae Simon, 1889 ) and Proshermacha Simon, 1908
(
Nemesiidae Simon, 1889 ), the genus Teyl reaches its highest diversity in the south-western land division of Western Australia , where they are a major component of the mygalomorph spider fauna. While a number of species are clearly dependent on southern-temperate mesic habitats in the far south of Western Australia (e.g. see Main 1985: 753–758 ), most occur in semi-arid or arid inland regions (
). Only six species have so far been described, including three from south-western Australia (see Main 1975 , 1983 , 1985 ) and three from western Victoria ( Main 2004 ). However, numerous undescribed species are present in Australian collections (MSH, MGR, unpubl. data), some of which were identified by
Castalanelli et al. (2014)
using barcoding molecular data, and including one ( Teyl sp. ‘BYM1953/2683’) formally listed as Critically Endangered under the Western Australian Wildlife Conservation Act 1950 (see Western Australian Government Gazette 2018 ).

This paper is the first in a planned series of systematic and revisionary treatments of the genera Teyl and Namea Raven, 1984 in Australia (i.e., the ‘ Teyl Group’ sensu Harvey et al . 2018
). We here document the Teyl specimens currently collected from Western Australia’s Pilbara bioregion, and describe the single known species at the northern extent of the genus’ distributional range. We further provide newly generated nucleotide sequence data for all described species of Teyl from Western Australia , and present an expanded phylogenetic assessment of the genus.

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p:
Taxonomic methods. All WA Museum specimens of Teyl currently known from the Pilbara bioregion of Western Australia were examined for this study, and are listed below and mapped (
) either as a named species or as unidentified juveniles. Specimens were examined and described in 70% ethanol under a Leica MZ16A dissecting microscope, following preservation in 70% or 95% ethanol. Digital images were taken using a Leica DFC500 camera attached to a Leica MZ16A microscope, and processed using Leica Application Suite (LAS) version 2.5.OR1 software. All measurements are in millimetres (to one decimal point), and total length measurements include the chelicerae, in dorsal view, but exclude the spinnerets. Leg I measurements were made along the dorsal edge of each segment, in prolateral view. Specimens are lodged at the Western Australian Museum, Perth (WAM) or the South Australian Museum, Adelaide (SAM). The following abbreviations are used throughout the text: ALE , anterior lateral eye/s
; AME , anterior median eye/s
; IBRA , Interim Biogeographic Regionalisation of Australia Version 7 (online at https://www.environment.gov.au/land/nrs/science/ibra
); PIL , Pilbara bioregion
; PLE , posterior lateral eye/s
; PME , posterior median eye/s
.

Molecular and laboratory methods. Nucleotide sequences were newly generated for three specimens of Teyl from the Pilbara bioregion, along with seven specimens of Teyl representing previously described species or species morphologically similar to named species ( Tables 1 , 2 ). Sequence data for all three species of Teyl currently described from Western Australia (i.e. T. damsonoides ( Main, 1983 )
, T. luculentusMain, 1975 and T. vancouveri ( Main, 1985 ))
were included ( T. damsonoides ) or newly sequenced ( T. luculentus , T. vancouveri ) for this study (with specimens sourced from at or near type localities in each instance), along with sequence data from four specimens from eastern South Australia , morphologically similar to the Victorian species T. harveyiMain 2004 or T. yeniMain 2004 . This combination of new Pilbara material and described species from type localities provided the molecular taxonomic framework required to apply an integrative species concept ( sensude Queiroz 2007 ), and to complement the morphological taxonomy. Laboratory methods for DNA extraction, polymerase chain reaction (PCR), nucleotide Sanger sequencing and downstream sequence editing were otherwise as per
Harvey et al. (2018)
, with the same seven loci targeted: cytochrome c oxidase subunit I ( COI ; mitochondrial); 12S ribosomal RNA (12S; mitochondrial); 16S ribosomal RNA (16S; mitochondrial); 18S ribosomal RNA (18S; nuclear); 28S ribosomal RNA (28S; nuclear); histone H3 ( H3 ; nuclear); and elongation factor-1γ ( EF-1γ ).

Phylogenetic analyses. A concatenated matrix consisting of 38 representative specimens from
Harvey et al. (2018)
was combined with the 10 specimens of Teyl newly sequenced for this study ( Tables 1 , 2 ), for a final molecular dataset of 48 specimens and seven loci. To avoid an unnecessarily dense sampling of non- Teyl Anamini
genera, a representative subset of at most five specimens from each genus were included in the final dataset, with Stanwellia nebulosa (Rainbow & Pulleine, 1918)
set as the ultimate outgroup. Alignments were carried out using the MAFFT plug-in in Geneious ( Katoh and Standley 2013 ). Due to the phylogenetic breadth of the dataset, ribosomal gene alignments had many regions that were difficult to align. Therefore, the program G Blocks ( Castresana 2000 ; Talavera and Castresana 2007 ) was used to remove phylogenetically uninformative sites. The web tool was chosen for this task (http://molevol.cmima.csic.es/castresana/Gblocks_server.html), and the settings allowed for gaps and larger blocks. The resulting alignments were: 12S (318 bp); 16S (405 bp); 18S (1,761 bp), 28S (753 bp); COI (658 bp); H3 (328 bp) and EF-1ɣ (882 bp). Trees were built for each alignment separately using the RAxML plug-in (version 7.2.8) ( Stamatakis 2006 ) in Geneious using default settings, with 1,000 bootstrap replicates. A concatenated TABLE 1 .
GenBank accession numbers for 48 specimens included in the molecular analyses. Highlighted (*) specimens of Teyl were newly sequenced for this study.

SAM = South Australian Museum; WAM = Western Australian Museum. alignment (5,105 bp) was also analysed. This concatenated dataset was partitioned using Partition Finder v1.1 ( Lanfear et al. 2012 , 2014 ), which identified three partitions: 12S, 16S, COI codon 1, and H3 codon 3 (partition1); 18S, 28S, COI codon 2, EF-1ɣ , H3 codons 1 and 2 (partition 2); and COI codon 3 (partition 3). These partitions were analysed with the GTR+G substitution model, using the RAxML plug-in in Geneious using default settings. The robustness of nodes was estimated using 1,000 bootstrap replicates, and the final tree was visualised and edited in FigTree (http://tree.bio.ed.ac.uk/software/figtree/).

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
Maximum Likelihood analysis of the concatenated dataset recovered an overall topology (
) congruent with that of
Harvey et al. (2018
, fig. 3). The Chenistonia Group, Teyl Group, Kwonkan Group and Aname Group of
Harvey et al. (2018)
were all monophyletic, and nested genera within each clade were recovered in the same relative phylogenetic positions, with high support (
). The Chenistonia Group was found to be sister to the Teyl Group, both of which were sister to the Aname Group plus Kwonkan Group.
TABLE 2. Collection data for 10 specimens newly sequenced for the molecular analyses. SAM = South Australian
Museum; WAM = Western Australian Museum.

mixed-citation.named-content: Open-holed trapdoor spiders of the genus Teyl (Mygalomorphae: Nemesiidae Anamini) from Western Australia’s Pilbara bioregion: a new species and expanded phylogenetic assessment

tp:taxon-treatment.tp:mixed-nomenclature:
Family
Nemesiidae Simon, 1889 Tribe Anamini Simon, 1889

tp:treatment-sec.p: Anamae Simon, 1889: 178 . Type genus Aname L. Koch, 1873 .
TeylMain, 1975: 74 . Type species by original designation Teyl luculentusMain, 1975 .

The diagnostic separation of Teyl and Namea is currently problematic, due largely to the absence of a phylogenetic hypothesis for Namea , and the presence of a number of confounding diagnostic characters at the generic level (an issue discussed in detail by Raven 1984 ). At present, Teyl includes all of those species which occur in western and southern Australia , outside of the subtropical and tropical mesic zone of eastern Queensland and north-eastern New South Wales . Whether Namea , as currently circumscribed ( sensuRaven 1984 ), represents one or more genera, and how it differs morphologically from Teyl s.s. , is currently the subject of ongoing research.

Included species. The genus Teyl includes seven described species, one of which is newly described in this study. Numerous undescribed species are also known from throughout western and southern Australia .

http://zoobank.org/
urn:lsid:zoobank.org:act: 38CC7541-19AD-444F-A99D-0DC200A3E73C

Teyl ‘MYG027’
Castalanelli et al. , 2014: 380
.

Type material.AUSTRALIA : Western Australia :
male holotype , Hamersley Range , Weeli Wolli Creek region , Area C , site 09-9E ( IBRA _ PIL ), 22°55’31”S , 119°02’16”E , pitfall trap , 15 June 2008 , P. Bolton , J. Puglisi (WAM T91918 )
.

Other material examined.Australia : Western Australia : 1 male , Angelo River ( IBRA _ PIL ), 23°19’36”S , 118°43’51”E , pitfall trap , 20 June–1 July 2011 , C. Trainor (WAM T115978); 1 male , Wonmunna , ca . 73 km heading 291° NW. from Newman ( IBRA _ PIL ), 23°07’16”S , 119°03’48”E , wide creek, wet pitfall trap , 20 May–22 June 2011 ,
P.R. Langlands (WAM T 112357 )
; 1 juvenile , Southern Flank , 72 km NW. of Newman ( IBRA _ PIL ), 23°00’10”S , 119°08’20”E , dug from burrow, 14 April 2011 , R. Teale, M. Greenham (WAM T113601).

Diagnosis. Males of Teyl heuretes can be distinguished from T. damsonoides by the presence of a reflexed embolus (
; cf. Main 1983 , fig. 51); from T. harveyi , T. vancouveri , and T. walkeri by the length of the embolus, which is much longer relative to the width of the bulb (
; cf. Main 1985 , fig. 24; Main 2004 , figs 8, 19); and from T. luculentus and T. yeni by the absence of conspicuous macrosetae on metatarsus I (
; cf. Main 1975 , fig. 2C; Main 2004 , fig. 35). Females are unknown.

Etymology. The specific epithet is derived from the Greek heuretes (finder, inventor, discoverer; see Brown 1956 ), in reference to the species with the most northern distribution of the genus (
), and for Keiran John (Jack) Devery, the maternal grandfather of the first author, who spent his life improving himself and learning new skills to discover the world around him.
Unidentified juvenile Teyl specimens from the Pilbara bioregion

Material examined.Australia : Western Australia : 1 juvenile , Newman area ( IBRA _ PIL ), 23°21’S , 119°44’E , 20–27 June 1984 , via D. Kaljuste (WAM T 44346 ); 1 juvenile , Mudlark , 100 km W. of Newman ( IBRA _ PIL ), 23°04’09”S , 118°47’28”E , dug from burrow, 2 July 2011 , M. Greenham, N. Watson (WAM T116806); 1 juvenile , same data except 111 km WNW. of Newman , 23°05’13”S , 118°41’11”E , 30 June 2011 , M. Greenham, J. Cairnes (WAM T116756); 2 juveniles , Wonmunna , ca . 72 km heading 290° from Newman ( IBRA _ PIL ), 23°07’42”S , 119°04’25”E , wet pitfall trap , 19 May–23 June 2011 , P.R. Langlands (WAM T 112356 ); 1 juvenile , same data except ca . 75 km heading 289° from Newman , 23°08’08”S , 119°02’18”E (WAM T 112355 ); 1 juvenile , same data except ca . 79 km heading 286° from Newman , 23°09’17”S , 118°59’36”E , dug from burrow, 18 May–22 June 2011 (WAM T 112358 ).

Teyl ‘MYG027’
Castalanelli et al. , 2014: 380
.

Type material.AUSTRALIA : Western Australia :
male holotype , Hamersley Range , Weeli Wolli Creek region , Area C , site 09-9E ( IBRA _ PIL ), 22°55’31”S , 119°02’16”E , pitfall trap , 15 June 2008 , P. Bolton , J. Puglisi (WAM T91918 )
.

Other material examined.Australia : Western Australia : 1 male , Angelo River ( IBRA _ PIL ), 23°19’36”S , 118°43’51”E , pitfall trap , 20 June–1 July 2011 , C. Trainor (WAM T115978); 1 male , Wonmunna , ca . 73 km heading 291° NW. from Newman ( IBRA _ PIL ), 23°07’16”S , 119°03’48”E , wide creek, wet pitfall trap , 20 May–22 June 2011 ,
P.R. Langlands (WAM T 112357 )
; 1 juvenile , Southern Flank , 72 km NW. of Newman ( IBRA _ PIL ), 23°00’10”S , 119°08’20”E , dug from burrow, 14 April 2011 , R. Teale, M. Greenham (WAM T113601).

Diagnosis. Males of Teyl heuretes can be distinguished from T. damsonoides by the presence of a reflexed embolus (
; cf. Main 1983 , fig. 51); from T. harveyi , T. vancouveri , and T. walkeri by the length of the embolus, which is much longer relative to the width of the bulb (
; cf. Main 1985 , fig. 24; Main 2004 , figs 8, 19); and from T. luculentus and T. yeni by the absence of conspicuous macrosetae on metatarsus I (
; cf. Main 1975 , fig. 2C; Main 2004 , fig. 35). Females are unknown.

Etymology. The specific epithet is derived from the Greek heuretes (finder, inventor, discoverer; see Brown 1956 ), in reference to the species with the most northern distribution of the genus (
), and for Keiran John (Jack) Devery, the maternal grandfather of the first author, who spent his life improving himself and learning new skills to discover the world around him.
Unidentified juvenile Teyl specimens from the Pilbara bioregion

Material examined.Australia : Western Australia : 1 juvenile , Newman area ( IBRA _ PIL ), 23°21’S , 119°44’E , 20–27 June 1984 , via D. Kaljuste (WAM T 44346 ); 1 juvenile , Mudlark , 100 km W. of Newman ( IBRA _ PIL ), 23°04’09”S , 118°47’28”E , dug from burrow, 2 July 2011 , M. Greenham, N. Watson (WAM T116806); 1 juvenile , same data except 111 km WNW. of Newman , 23°05’13”S , 118°41’11”E , 30 June 2011 , M. Greenham, J. Cairnes (WAM T116756); 2 juveniles , Wonmunna , ca . 72 km heading 290° from Newman ( IBRA _ PIL ), 23°07’42”S , 119°04’25”E , wet pitfall trap , 19 May–23 June 2011 , P.R. Langlands (WAM T 112356 ); 1 juvenile , same data except ca . 75 km heading 289° from Newman , 23°08’08”S , 119°02’18”E (WAM T 112355 ); 1 juvenile , same data except ca . 79 km heading 286° from Newman , 23°09’17”S , 118°59’36”E , dug from burrow, 18 May–22 June 2011 (WAM T 112358 ).

sec.title: Acknowledgements
sec.p: We would like to thank the various collectors of Teyl specimens from the Pilbara bioregion, without which this work would not have been possible. This study was funded by the Gorgon Barrow Island Net Conservation Benefits Fund. This fund is administered by the Department of Biodiversity, Conservation and Attractions (Western Australia) and approved by the Minister for Environment after considering advice from the Gorgon Barrow Island Net Conservation Benefits Advisory Board. Additional funding was also provided to MGR and JDW by the Australian Biological Resources Study Taxonomy Research Grants Scheme (ABRS Grant No. RG18-03).
